unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: 2 Proportion z-Intervals: 1-sided Testing
question_text:
A two-sample $z$-test for proportions had the hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }=0$$
$${ H }_{ a }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }<0$$
The test produces a $p$-value of $0.043$.
Which of the following must be TRUE?
I. A $90\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
II. A $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
III. A $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
solution:
We want the interval to contain $0$, meaning we fail to reject the null hypotheses. Notice in this case that the alternative hypotheses is one-sided, whereas the confidence interval measures $2$-sided. The easiest way to approach this is to make the alternative two-sided by doubling the $p$-value. Our new $p$-value will be $0.086$.

In order to solve for this, we need to calculate the significance level of each one of the intervals and then see if the $p$-value falls above or below the level.

Statement I. For a $90\%$ confidence interval, the significance level is $10\%$. Since our $p$-value of $0.086 < 0.10$, we reject the null hypotheses. Therefore, Statement I is false.

Statement II. For a $95\%$ confidence interval, the significance level is $5\%$. Since our $p$-value of $0.086>0.05$, we fail to reject the null hypotheses. Therefore, Statement II is TRUE.

Statement III. For a $99\%$ confidence interval, the significance level is $1\%$. Since our $p$-value of $0.086>0.01$, we fail to reject the null hypotheses. Therefore, Statement III is TRUE.
